comment:
"Lasker gave in one of his books ("Chess for Fun
and Chess for Blood", I believe) the order 1 d4 f5 2 Nf3 e6 3 Nc3, with a
comment about  White's third move not being good." (Marshall Chess Club 23.01.
2001)  Of course, if 3 Nc3 is not good after 1 d4 f5 2 Nf3 e6, then it will
also not be good after 1 d4 e6 2 Nf3 f5.  It is natural to want to believe
Edward Lasker himself, but, unfortunately he gave different versions of the
game in different places, so he must have goofed at least once, and possibly
more than once.  "Chess for Fun and Chess  for Blood", was written decades
after the game was played.  The other occasion when Edward Lasker wrote about
the game was six years after the event.  Edward Winter found the 1 d4 e6 2 Nf3
f5 3 Nc3 Nf6 4 Bg5 Be7 5 Bxf6 Bxf6 6 e4 fxe4 7 Nxe4 b6  8 Ne5 0-0 9 Bd3 Bb7
version in Bachmann's  Schachjahrbuch 1912.  Richard Forster said that  this
version was also given in "the column in De  Amsterdammer, 17 November 1912,
by Loman,  who was a regular at the City of London Chess  Club". (Louis Blair
RGCM 24.01.2001)  3...

moves: 1. d4 f5 2. e4 fxe4 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 e6 5. Nxe4 Be7 6. Bxf6 Bxf6 7. Nf3 b6 8. Ne5 O-O 9. Bd3 Bb7
comment:
There is some dispute about the order of the first few
moves of this game. Richard Foster thought that the best guess was 1 d4 e6 2
Nf3 f5 3 Nc3 Nf6 4 Bg5 Be7 5 Bxf6 Bxf6 6 e4 fxe4 7 Nxe4 b6 8 Ne5 0-0 9 Bd3 Bb7.
  More on this subject can be found in Edward Winter's book, Chess
Explorations. (Louis Blair - RGCM 21/01/01 )

moves: 1. d4 f5 2. e4 fxe4 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 e6 5. Nxe4 Be7 6. Bxf6 Bxf6 7. Nf3 b6 8. Ne5 O-O 9. Bd3 Bb7 10. Qh5 Qe7 11. Qxh7+
comment:
A sacrifice of the Queen
leading to a forced mate of rare beauty: with a King move! 11...

moves: 1. d4 f5 2. e4 fxe4 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 e6 5. Nxe4 Be7 6. Bxf6 Bxf6 7. Nf3 b6 8. Ne5 O-O 9. Bd3 Bb7 10. Qh5 Qe7 11. Qxh7+ Kxh7 12. Nxf6+ Kh6
comment:
"Jeremy Silman wrote in his CL column something about how he
had often attempted to repeat that game but never managed it, the closest I
came was in a net game where I got as far as 11 Qh7+ Kh7 12 Nf6+ but then the
guy played ...Kh8. Pretty disappointing."(Marshall Chess Club - 23.01.2001)  I
wonder if it is really a good idea to try to immitate this game.  If I
remember correctly,  John Nunn did not think that White had a  particularly
good position after the natural move, 10... Bxe5. (Louis Blair - RGCM 24.01.
2001)

moves: 1. d4 f5 2. e4 fxe4 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 e6 5. Nxe4 Be7 6. Bxf6 Bxf6 7. Nf3 b6 8. Ne5 O-O 9. Bd3 Bb7 10. Qh5 Qe7 11. Qxh7+ Kxh7 12. Nxf6+ Kh6 13. Neg4+ Kg5 14. h4+ Kf4 15. g3+ Kf3 16. Be2+ Kg2 17. Rh2+ Kg1 18. Kd2#
comment:
Funny!  "In the same mentioned above Edward Lasker
gives the last move as Kd2 and not 0-0-0, which you also  sometimes see.
Tastes vary but I always preferred Kd2, since the rook mates from  farther
away." (Marshall Chess Club - RGCM 23/01/01)
